title: Webcam Feeds of New York City Draw Viewers
summary: Folks around the world who can't board a plane use cams to 'travel' to the city. When streaming video service VUit launched in September, the coronavirus upended its plans to broadcast live shows from its Manhattan studio. On a whim, employees turned the studio's camera out the window to face the nondescript corner of Sixth Avenue and 39th Street. The 24-hour street-scene feed quickly became the service's most popular channel, beating out dozens of live news and sports broadcasts.

title: Trump Campaign Asks Supreme Court to Overturn Biden's Wisconsin Win
summary: Unless court expedites case, the appeal likely will be moot before it comes up for consideration by the justices. WASHINGTON-The Trump campaign said Tuesday it was asking the Supreme Court to overturn President-elect Joe Biden's victory in Wisconsin, following a similar appeal it filed last week seeking to reverse the Democrat's win in Pennsylvania.

title: Some Americans to Receive $600 Stimulus Payments Tonight, Mnuchin Says
summary: Treasury secretary says paper checks will begin to be sent Wednesday; some direct deposits will take longer. Americans will start seeing $600 stimulus payments from the latest Covid-19 relief legislation land in their bank accounts as soon as Tuesday night, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said.

title: Louisville Moves to Fire Two Officers Connected to Breonna Taylor Killing
summary: Joshua Jaynes, who wrote search warrant, and Myles Cosgrove, who fired weapon at the scene, received pre-termination notices. The Louisville, Ky., police department is moving to fire two detectives connected to the killing of Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old Black woman, during a nighttime raid in March.

title: Justice Department Says Pearl's Accused Killer Could Be Tried in U.S.
summary: If Pakistanis fail to keep suspect imprisoned, U.S. stands ready, acting attorney general says. The U.S. Justice Department on Tuesday raised the possibility that a man accused in the 2002 murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl could be brought to the U.S. and tried here after a Pakistani court earlier this month ordered him set free.

title: Two Officers in Tamir Rice's Fatal Shooting Won't Face Federal Charges
summary: Action closes probe into case that helped spark conversation on police use of force against Black Americans. Federal prosecutors said Tuesday they wouldn't bring federal charges against two police officers in the fatal shooting of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Cleveland boy who was killed in 2014 while playing with a toy gun.

title: Your 2021 Budget: Plan Ahead, but Not Too Far Ahead
summary: Resume Subscription. The year 2020 taught us to expect the unexpected. For the year ahead, consider making a budget with that in mind.

title: U.S. Reports First Case of Virus Variant
summary: Fast-spreading form of coronavirus is found in Colorado man in his 20s who had no history of travel. Colorado reported the first case in the U.S. of a fast-spreading variant of Covid-19 that was first detected in the U.K. and led to a widespread lockdown and travel restrictions there.

title: Moderna to Offer Vaccine to Workers, Contractors and Board
summary: Company says move will provide additional layer of protection to workers making and delivering vaccine. Moderna Inc. said Tuesday it will offer its new Covid-19 vaccine to its own employees, contractors and board members in a move the company said would provide an additional layer of protection to workers involved in making and delivering the vaccine.

title: Facial Recognition in Spotlight in New Jersey False-Arrest Case
summary: Black man police detained for more than a week sues authorities after use of technology that some cities have banned over racial bias concerns. A New Jersey man is suing local authorities who he says wrongly arrested him based on a false facial-recognition match, in a case that has fueled debate over the accuracy of the fast-emerging technology.

title: McConnell Blocks Holding Quick Vote on $2,000 Checks
summary: Majority leader insists on combining bill for $2,000 checks with Trump agenda items. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell moved to derail efforts to quickly pass larger stimulus checks for many Americans, blocking Democrats' call for a stand-alone vote on the payments sought by President Trump but opposed by most Republicans.

title: Scapegoating Walmart
summary: The feds seek billions in penalties for filling valid opioid prescriptions.. One benefit of the Trump era has been the relative absence of dubious lawsuits against business. An exception is the Justice Department's new suit against Walmart for filling opioid prescriptions.

title: China Jails a Covid Reporter
summary: 'Why can't I show the truth?' Zhang Zhan dared to ask.. A Chinese court Monday sentenced 37-year-old Zhang Zhan to four years in prison for "picking quarrels and provoking trouble," but her real offense was telling the truth about the government's early mishandling of Covid.

title: McConnell at the Bridge
summary: The Senate leader tries to minimize the harm from a vengeful Trump.. President Trump has always put his personal interests above nearly everything else, and Republicans are paying the political price. Mr. Trump lost his re-election bid to Joe Biden, and now he may cost Republicans the Senate too.

title: A Hasty Withdrawal From Somalia
summary: Trump's late pullout appears to put politics over antiterror strategy.. U.S. troops can't be everywhere forever. But the Trump Administration hasn't made a good case for its recently announced withdrawal from Somalia in Northeast Africa.

title: College in the Time of Covid
summary: Students reflect on their experience of the pandemic as 2020 comes to a close.. Editor's note: This week's Future View asks students what they learned from living amid the Covid-19 pandemic. For the next installment we'll ask, "The 1918 flu pandemic precipitated the roaring '20s. Do you anticipate the end of Covid-19 having a similar effect?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Jan. 12. The best responses will be published that night.

title: The Policy Lessons of the 'Trump Economy'
summary: Presidents are often at the mercy of unpredictable factors like the business cycle-and pandemics.. President Trump's supporters tout the economy's pre-pandemic performance as evidence that tax cuts and deregulation were making America great again. Detractors look at the data and find these policies wanting or outweighed by the harmful effects of Mr. Trump's aggressive approach to trade and his isolationist approach to immigration.

title: America Is Willing to Pay for Change
summary: Covid-19 worsened a shortage of coins. Capitalism is solving the problem.. Making change used to be a bit of a joke. A memorable "Saturday Night Live" parody ad in 1988 imagined the "First CityWide Change Bank," which gave its customers the denominations they want: "If you come to us with a $100 bill, we're not going to give you 2,000 nickels-unless that meets your particular change needs."

title: Revolution Consumes New York's Elite Dalton School
summary: Teachers of $54,000 Zoom classes demand a lowering of standards and hiring of a dozen diversity staffers.. The Dalton School, an elite private prep school in New York's Upper East Side, is experiencing something of a moral panic, and not about whether or not to have spring sports during Covid-19. On Dec. 18 my blog, The Naked Dollar, revealed a list of race-based demands from 120 Dalton teachers. The Naked Dollar isn't particularly well-known, but the story quickly went global.

title: The Slow Birth of Covid Realism
summary: Can we now admit that herd immunity and vaccines will work in tandem?. Italy, last seen trying to prosecute government scientists for failing to forecast an earthquake, is now pioneering the use of criminal prosecutors to examine the country's Covid-19 response. Italy as a country ranks low on every index of efficient, accountable government and effective legal system. Criminalizing policy disappointments and managerial errors is a symptom of this failure, not its cure.

title: 'The Story of Evolution in 25 Discoveries' Review: The Branching Tree of Life
summary: Biological classiﬁcation conforms perfectly with the patterns of evolutionary relationships evidenced by anatomy, physiology and genetics.. The great but grumpy biologist J.B.S. Haldane was once asked what evidence would disprove evolution, whereupon he growled: "Fossil rabbits in the Precambrian." He was referring to the evolutionary fact that complex multicellular creatures came along later than simple, unicellular ones. A bit surprising, perhaps, that one of the foremost evolutionary geneticists of the 20th century immediately reached for a paleontological example, but Haldane's reply was well-suited for public consumption, because then-as now-when most people thought of evolution, they were likely to conjure images of dinosaur fossils.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Media's Addiction
summary: 'Praise from anti-Trump celebrities on Twitter has become like a "narcotic" for some.'. McKay Coppinswriting for the Atlantic, Dec. 29:

title: Who Gets to Vote in Georgia?
summary: An argument over postal records.. A legal ruling in Georgia seems unlikely to reassure those concerned about the accuracy of voter rolls in the Peach State. Kyle Cheney and Josh Gerstein report in Politico:

title: What to Know About Unemployment Benefits in Covid-19 Aid Package
summary: Two special pandemic-related programs are extended through March 14, and recipients of regular state benefits get an extra $300. President Trump on Dec. 27 signed a $900 billion aid package into law that expands the amount and duration of unemployment benefits available to millions of laid-off workers. The law extends two pandemic-related programs used by 14 million people and provides for a period of supplemental $300 payments to all recipients of unemployment benefits.

title: Third Point Calls on Intel to Explore Strategic Alternatives
summary: Activist hedge fund says it has taken significant stake in Intel, calls for changes to preserve U.S. edge in semiconductor industry. Activist hedge fund Third Point LLC pressed Intel Corp. to make sweeping strategic changes after a year in which the U.S. semiconductor giant suffered more product delays and lost its rank as America's highest-valued chip company.

title: Appellate Court Rules Minority Party in House Can Demand Records
summary: Judicial decision, sought by Democrats in 2017, could boost GOP oversight of Biden administration. A federal appeals court on Tuesday ruled that members of the minority party in the House of Representatives are entitled to demand and receive records from a presidential administration without the consent of the majority party in some circumstances.

title: Boeing's 737 MAX Returns to U.S. Commercial Service
summary: Flight from Miami to New York is aircraft's first in U.S. since being grounded nearly two years ago following deadly crashes. American Airlines Group Inc. put passengers back on Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX for the first time in the U.S. since the aircraft was grounded nearly two years ago following two deadly crashes.

title: 'The Watch' Review: Making Fantasy Fun
summary: This adaptation of Terry Pratchett's Discworld novels is a comic journey into dystopian ideas.. Terry Pratchett's Discworld, the setting of 41 novels by the phenomenally prolific author, was carried on the back of four elephants and a turtle. Its TV incarnation, "The Watch," is carried by Richard Dormer, Northern Irish actor and "Game of Thrones" veteran. His Commander Sam Vimes, as we see in episode 1, begins his career as an idealistic member of what passes for a police force in the Discworld locale of Ankh-Morpork. But after the emptying of "9321 bottles of booze," the loss of "68,242 brain cells" and the neutering of law enforcement by the city's administration, he has become a combination of Popeye and Keith Richards, a scowling, ambling, slightly addlepated detective who will still rise-albeit with considerable difficulty-to the occasion.

title: Defense Bill Proposes to Expand SEC's Authority in Seeking Disgorgement
summary: The annual defense policy bill, if passed, would give the SEC the power to recover ill-gotten gains over a longer period. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission would have broadened authority to seek ill-gotten gains in enforcement actions as part of an annual defense-spending bill that is awaiting a critical Senate vote.

title: Stocks Give Up Gains
summary: S&P 500 falls after closing at fresh high on Monday. U.S. stocks slipped Tuesday, halting a recent rally that has sent major benchmarks to fresh records.

title: Hyperpop's Joyful Too-Muchness
summary: The genre, which takes familiar sounds from electronic pop, rap and dance and intensifies them through compression, distortion and exaggeration, broke into the mainstream this year thanks to figures like 100 Gecs and A.G. Cook..

title: Kushner Cos. Plans $100 Million Bond Sale in Israel
summary: Company plan is likely to rekindle criticism of potential conflicts of interest between Jared Kushner's role in White House and his family's business. Kushner Cos., the family business of White House senior aide Jared Kushner, filed papers to raise at least $100 million by selling bonds in Israel.

title: Pierre Cardin, Fashion Designer of the Space Age, Dies at 98
summary: Resume Subscription. PARIS-Pierre Cardin, the designer whose Space Age clothes made him a progenitor of avant-garde fashion and who later earned a fortune-and criticism-licensing his name to hundreds of mass-market products, died Tuesday in the French capital region. He was 98 years old.

title: What to Know About Unemployment Benefits in Covid-19 Aid Package
summary: Two special pandemic-related programs are extended through March 14, and recipients of regular state benefits get an extra $300. President Trump on Dec. 27 signed a $900 billion aid package into law that expands the amount and duration of unemployment benefits available to millions of laid-off workers. The law extends two pandemic-related programs used by 14 million people and provides for a period of supplemental $300 payments to all recipients of unemployment benefits.

title: In at the Finish (Wednesday Crossword, December 30)
New U.S. Dietary Guidelines Reject Recommendation to Cut Sugar, Alcohol Intake Limit
summary: A scientific advisory committee had advised lower limits on sugar and alcohol, citing health risks. The federal government on Tuesday issued new dietary guidelines that keep current allowances for sugar and alcohol consumption unchanged, rejecting recommendations by its scientific advisory committee to make significant cuts.

title: Mexico Set to Become World's Largest Legal Cannabis Market
summary: Resume Subscription. MEXICO CITY-Mexico is home to the world's most powerful drug cartels, who have terrorized the country for years. But the country is poised to try something different in tackling the gangs by legalizing at least one of their products: marijuana.

title: Pierre Cardin: From a Tailor's Cutter to Fashion Mogul
summary: Pierre Cardin was first to democratize high fashion and develop his name as a brand. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Ebenezer Scrooge Can't Be Made Into a Hero
summary: Capitalism errs in thinking that putting sin to good use will transform it into virtue.. Phil Gramm and Mike Solon's "In Defense of Scrooge, Whose Thrift Blessed the World" (op-ed, Dec. 24) is a witty and intelligent defense of capitalism with a moral error. The genius of capitalism is that it harnesses human greed to the common good-but greed itself remains a sin. We are reminded of this every time a company uses foreign slave labor to bring down prices or calculates that the lawsuits arising from a safety glitch will cost it less than fixing the danger before anyone gets hurt. It may be good business, but it's bad living.

title: The Vaccine Is Here. Can We End Lockdowns?
summary: Trust has been placed in experts who have focused almost exclusively on medical imperatives.. In Jay Bhattacharya and Sunetra Gupta's "How to End Lockdowns Next Month" (op-ed, Dec. 18), hope triumphs over fact. In arguing for an end to lockdowns once vulnerable populations have been vaccinated, their analysis assumes that there is a binary outcome from Covid-19 infections: Either it kills you or it's no threat at all.

title: How Clogs Clomped Back Into Style (Seriously)
summary: Chunky clogs have become improbably trendy, with brands like Chanel, Hermès and Louis Vuitton offering high-fashion takes. Here, the footwear's surprising history, from Dutch workers' shoes to the Paris runways.. ON HER FIRST date with Joe Biden, in 1975, Jill Biden, then a college student at the University of Delaware, immediately noticed his shoes. As she later recounted, "I had been dating guys in jeans and clogs and T-shirts, he came to the door and he had a sport coat and loafers and I thought, 'God, this is never going to work, not in a million years.'"

title: Can We Address Race, IQ and Intellectual Cowardice?
summary: Jason Riley is right to highlight the work of James Flynn.. In "An Intelligent Discussion About Race and IQ Is Possible" (Upward Mobility, Dec. 16), Jason Riley is right to highlight the work of James Flynn. The late researcher of the complex genetic and environmental factors relating to intelligence believed, as Mr. Riley puts it, that "dodging difficult topics was intellectual cowardice." That brings to mind cancel culture, the apotheosis of intellectual cowardice. Does the need to shut down discussion, out of fear or plain rage, have its roots in genetic or environmental factors? We should study that, too.

title: One Solution to the Problem of Enemy Computer Hackers
summary: Why does the U.S. continues to connect highly sensitive systems to the internet?. News of "Russia's SolarWinds Hack" (Review & Outlook, Dec. 19) compounds my amazement that the U.S. continues to connect highly sensitive systems to the internet. I hear the response already: We can't possibly go back-it would take so much time to move information. Yes, it would. But how many more times will we be robbed blind of defense secrets and other precious assets before the convenience of instant access begins to seem too costly?

title: 'There Was a Piece Missing-We Were All White': One Bank Targets Racial Inequity
summary: Companies across the U.S. are pledging to hire and promote more women and people of color, in many cases saying they want to make their workplaces reflect their customers. Boston-based Eastern Bank has made sustained efforts yet still says 'we have a long way to go.'. Eastern Bankshares Inc. isn't the largest bank in Boston, or the most profitable. But in its hometown-and across the country-it stands out as a company with historically white leadership where sustained efforts to promote racial diversity have taken root.

title: Health-Costs Transparency Rule for Hospitals Upheld on Appeal
summary: Federal appeals court turns back suit from hospital group arguing providers couldn't legally be compelled to disclose rates negotiated in secret with insurers. WASHINGTON-A federal appeals court in Washington affirmed a Trump administration policy requiring hospitals to disclose secret rates they negotiate with insurance companies beginning on Friday, marking a victory for one of President Trump's central health-policy initiatives.

title: Mild Winter Weather Hammers Natural Gas in December
summary: Recent forecasts show warmer temperatures spreading across the U.S. in the next few weeks, driving an unwind of bullish bets. Natural-gas prices are heading for their second consecutive big monthly drop, stung by warmer-than-expected weather forecasts that are denting demand for the heating fuel.

title: A Start at Bridging the Partisan Gulf
summary: Fringes aside, the right and left can compromise based on shared principles.. As this difficult year slinks to its unlamented end, I have felt compelled to ask myself: What do I believe so much that if necessary I will fight for it the way America's revolutionaries did, with their lives, fortunes and sacred honor? And how do my beliefs compare with the widening spectrum of beliefs about America?

title: The Oil Industry Is Stuck in Virus Alley
summary: Prices won't break out of the $40 to $50 range until consumption gets back to normal sometime next year.. When will oil sustainably break out of the "Virus Alley"-that $40 to $50 band that has held oil prices in check for months? That's Question No. 1 going into 2021 for an oil industry that has dramatically retrenched and investors who have abandoned the sector because of a lack of returns. It will also determine when U.S. shale recovers from its pandemic malaise and resumes growth.

title: Inside the Google-Facebook Ad Deal
summary: Lawmakers have called for an investigation into the tech giants' contract, dubbed 'Jedi Blue,' which allegedly allowed for auction rigging. State attorneys general said in a lawsuit earlier this month that a 2018 business agreement between two digital advertising giants, Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google, was an illegal price-fixing deal. Lawmakers are calling for further investigation. The companies say it was above board.

title: Columbus, Ohio, Police Officer Fired After Killing Black Man
summary: White officer Adam Coy didn't turn on body camera until after shooting and delayed providing first aid, authorities said. The Columbus, Ohio, police officer who fatally shot an unarmed Black man last week was fired, city officials said Monday.

title: John Densmore Says He Owes His Rock Career to an Unlikely Source: 'My Orthodontist'
summary: Braces prevented The Doors drummer from playing the clarinet or trombone in junior high. John Densmore, 75, is a drummer and an original member of The Doors. He is the author of the memoirs "Riders on the Storm," "The Doors: Unhinged" and, most recently, "The Seekers: Meetings with Remarkable Musicians" (Hachette). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Pandemic Leads Schools to Halt Ph.D. Admissions
summary: More than 140 humanities and social sciences programs at top schools have suspended admitting students for fall 2021. The coronavirus pandemic threw doctoral programs, like nearly everything else, into disarray. Now some department chairs see an opportunity for reform.

title: Three Ways to Hibernate in Vermont During Covid
summary: Vermont is a tough place to visit this winter, but if you don't want to socialize, here's where to quarantine cozily. HIDING OUT in Vermont's snowy Green Mountains presents some challenges during Covid-times-but that's the allure. The state's strict regulations, wide-open spaces and intelligent epidemic management have led to one of the country's lowest rates of infection. A tough place to visit, Vermont requires all out-of-state travelers to quarantine for seven days if they have a negative Covid test or 14 days without one-either before they leave home or after arrival. The state also limits locals and visitors alike from gathering with people from other households. Lodgings and restaurants and even ski resorts, however, are open at limited capacity.

title: EU Member States Approve Trade Deal With U.K.
summary: Agreement sets out post-Brexit trade, security and economic ties. European Union member states formally backed last week's trade deal between the U.K. and the EU setting out post-Brexit trade, security and economic ties.

title: Fed, Treasury Provide One-Week Reprieve for 'Main Street' Program
summary: Treasury Department had earlier said program would close Dec. 31, triggering last-minute lending crush. The Treasury Department and Federal Reserve said Tuesday they had extended the cutoff date for the Main Street Lending Program from Dec. 31 to Jan. 8 to process a last-minute crush to deliver loans.

title: China Eyes Shrinking Jack Ma's Business Empire
summary: The state could take a bigger stake in the billionaire's businesses as regulators beef up oversight of the powerful tech sector. Beijing is seeking to shrink Jack Ma's technology and financial empire and potentially take a larger stake in his businesses, according to Chinese officials and government advisers familiar with the matter, as regulators zero in on the billionaire in a campaign to strengthen oversight of an increasingly influential tech sphere.

title: House Votes to Override Trump Veto of Defense Bill
summary: Defense measure now goes to Senate, is poised to be first bill to become law over Trump's objections. WASHINGTON-The House on Monday voted to override President Trump's veto of a $740.5 billion defense policy bill, sending the bill to the Senate and putting it on track to be the first legislation to become law over Mr. Trump's objections.

title: German Town Finds a Blueprint for Lowering Covid-19 Deaths
summary: From free tests to the shielding of care homes, Tübingen has pioneered tools later deployed elsewhere to minimize pandemic casualties. Concern is growing in Europe over access to vaccine doses during the winter wave of Covid-19. But one town claims to have found a formula to prevent high mortality without a draconian lockdown.

title: Lamborghini, Maserati, T-Bucket: Our Favorite My Ride Cars of 2020
summary: Resume Subscription. For many, 2020 will go down as the strangest year in memory. One thing has remained constant, however. The love affair between Americans and their motoring machinery endures. Every week The Wall Street Journal's My Ride column profiles vehicles and owners with surprising stories. Here's a look back on some highlights of 2020.

title: SAP Unit Qualtrics Heads for IPO
summary: German business software giant SAP paid around $8 billion for the startup two years ago, in one of the biggest acquisitions ever. German business software giant SAP SE said it would return Qualtrics International Inc. to public markets, in a listing expected to value the business at least 50% above what it paid for the startup two years ago.

title: New Cases Challenge China's Targeted Covid-19 Strategy
summary: Latest infection clusters come as country prepares for explosion of travel around Lunar New Year holiday. HONG KONG-A string of new Covid-19 clusters poses a test to China's more targeted approach toward pandemic control as the country draws closer to the Lunar New Year holiday, typically a time when hundreds of millions of Chinese people travel to see relatives.

title: Politico to Acquire Energy Trade Publication E&E News
summary: Purchase comes as Politico looks to expand its overall professional news business. Politico is adding some energy to its game.

title: Superhero Franchise Creators Nervous of World Without Big-Screen Debuts
summary: 'Wonder Woman 1984' producer Charles Roven says theatrical model is the lifeblood of franchise films. This Christmas weekend, millions of movie lovers tuned in to watch Wonder Woman fly across their televisions instead of on towering movie screens. While convenient for some and for others the only way to see the movie, the creators of the production describe streaming as a regrettable medium for superhero films.

title: All I Want for Sports in 2021? You!
summary: Please forgive the Mariah Carey homage. But the return of games underlines the madness still absent from the experience.. We've got a day or two left in 2020, but I'm ready to close out the tab and call it a year. How about you? Usually around now, I do one of those "Best of the Year" lists, with flowery superlatives about sports items I witnessed, but that doesn't feel right.

title: How NYSE's Top Salesman Fought for IPOs in 2020
summary: Resume Subscription. During a record year for initial public offerings, John Tuttle spent five months urging companies to list on the New York Stock Exchange from his lakeside vacation house in Michigan where he took refuge during the coronavirus pandemic.

summary: U.S. stock futures point to an extension in market rally a day after the major indexes hit new highs. Here's what we're watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.

title: U.S. Home-Price Growth Accelerated in October
summary: The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index rose 8.4% as sales hit a 14-year high. Home-price growth accelerated in October, as strong demand pushed home sales to a 14-year high.

title: Dow Chemical Backs Effort to Use New York City's Drinking Water on Long Island
summary: Resume Subscription. Long Island earned a distinction in 2016 it didn't want: Some of the region's drinking water was found to have among the highest levels nationwide of 1,4-dioxane, a chemical the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency calls a "likely human carcinogen" but doesn't regulate.

title: School Went Online This Year, Including MIT's Swimming Test
summary: Resume Subscription. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology swim test-a 100-yard paddle required to graduate-hung over Megan Ochalek for four long years.

title: Lip Balms That Won't Stick to a Mask
summary: Not only is chapped lip season here, but mask-wearing can create the same "burn" effect as constantly licking your lips. How to heal them-without creating a gloopy sticky mess. The lipstick index is a term Leonard Lauder coined in 2001 to describe the affordable luxury products (like lipstick) that seem to be recession-proof. But COVID may have killed the lipstick index once and for all: When you're wearing a mask most of the time, does lipstick matter as much?

title: Smoother by the Dozen
summary: Our twelve favorite lip balms (and masks that do double duty as a balm) that will withstand both the elements and nonstop mask-wearing.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Shipping Faces New Turmoil in European Emissions Trading Plan
summary: The EU wants to include ships in its carbon trading plan, but the move divides the industry and risks derailing global cooperation on antipollution efforts. Cooperation in the shipping industry to cut pollution from oceangoing vessels is running aground in Europe.

title: London Sphere Project Might Get Post-Pandemic Push
summary: Proposed venue will likely face less competition, could benefit from traffic changes brought by increased working from home. An ambitious plan by Madison Square Garden Entertainment Corp. to develop a futuristic globe-shaped venue in a London suburb has become mired in red tape and controversy.

title: Tech Choices Dictate Teen Friendships During Pandemic
summary: The use of Snapchat, Instagram or TikTok can fray or strengthen ties, depending on whether pals communicate the same way. For many teenagers, the past year has been a blur of online classes, remote extracurriculars and virtual holiday celebrations. The shift to small-screen living might not seem like a major adjustment for teens already glued to their devices, but it has reshaped what is most critical to them: their friendships.

title: Georgia Military Who Backed Biden Could Help Determine Senate Control
summary: Trump's veto of defense authorization bill becomes a focus in Senate runoffs. President-elect Joe Biden's narrow victory in Georgia last month was driven in part by shifts toward the Democratic ticket in a collection of nine counties with strong ties to the military.

title: Post-Pandemic, Office Life May Never Be the Same, CIOs Say
summary: The conventional office and its desktop workspaces will become 'pre-Covid artifacts,' one CIO says. After working remotely for the better part of a year, employees have proven they can do it, and do it despite the difficulties being at home may have presented. Going forward, that means that where people work may have changed permanently, according to chief information officers.

title: CIOs Question a Full Return to the Office
summary: Remote work disrupted the traditional office in 2020. Opinions among CIOs and their employees vary on whether they prefer the physical office or remote work, as the pandemic continues to force more people to work from home.

title: Japan Group to Lend Vietnam $1.8 Billion for Coal-Fired Power
summary: Tokyo bucks backlash from investors and its own environment minister, citing project's contribution to economic development. TOKYO-A Japanese-led group said it would extend nearly $1.8 billion in loans to build a coal-fired power plant in Vietnam, bucking criticism about the project's impact on climate goals.

title: Blumberg Joins Rush of Property Firms Raising Funds for Distressed Deals
summary: Company to raise $1 billion next year to buy high-quality office buildings; 'It will be the best buying opportunity since 2010'. Blumberg Capital Partners is joining the growing number of real-estate investment firms raising capital in anticipation of a wave of distressed commercial properties hitting the market as a result of the pandemic.

title: Return to Almost Normal May Be Closer Than You Think
summary: U.S. doesn't need to reach full herd immunity before public spaces can begin phased reopenings. As 2021 arrives, there is one question that matters most: How soon can we escape the Covid-19 pandemic?

title: Pandemic Reshapes U.S. Employment Across Industries
summary: Economy has recouped 12 million of 22 million jobs lost in 2020, with uneven setbacks and recoveries in various sectors likely to outlast health crisis. The pandemic and related restrictions shocked the U.S. job market earlier this year, leading to a labor-force reordering as the economy recovered. Jobs have declined at retail stores, restaurants and bars and grown at warehouse and transportation businesses that serve online customers as e-commerce flourishes.

title: Slack Deal Shows Big Tech's Handcuffs
summary: Competing bids to Salesforce's offer didn't emerge, even after news of firms' merger talks surfaced. One of the largest tech deals this year also shows why there might be a lot fewer of them in the future.

title: Green Energy Will Need More Storage Space
summary: As the rollout of wind and solar picks up speed, solutions to bridge their intermittency are likely to take off too. The rapid growth of wind and solar power comes with a well-known problem: They don't work all the time. Energy storage is a solution investors should watch in 2021, even if it doesn't yet lend itself to stock picking.

title: These Tech Firms Pay Workers the Same Rates Across U.S.
summary: A handful of startups and larger firms are experimenting with nationally competitive, nonlocalized pay. Is the extra cost worth the added employee goodwill?. Tech workers and employers alike are beginning to question location-focused pay scales. A handful of companies are moving to abandon them altogether.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Outlook Revives Return-to-Office Plans
summary: Widespread return isn't likely until late spring or early summer of 2021. Office-building landlords are hoping that the massive Covid-19 vaccination campaign launched in the U.S. this month will lead to millions of people returning to workplaces in 2021 after spending most of the pandemic working from home.

title: Rare Small-Business Win Keeps Hope Alive for Insurance Payouts
summary: Resume Subscription. Chef Matthew Kelly is one of the few restaurateurs who has fought property insurers over pandemic business restrictions and won.

title: Covid-19 Deals Different Hands for Family Finances
summary: Resume Subscription. There's no single Covid-19 economy. There are a thousand.

title: How the 2020 QE Boom Might Trip Up Central Bankers
summary: A burst of central bank bond-buying has revived a debate about quantitative easing's potential fiscal cost. The Federal Reserve, European Central Bank and Bank of Japan have collectively expanded their balance sheets by around $8 trillion in 2020. It took them almost eight years to achieve the same growth following the seizure of global financial markets in September 2008.
